patterns: I need help with my neuroscience class

patterns: Are neurons the only type of brain cell
responses: No, only 50% of the cells in your brain are neurons. The other 50% are glial cells
Glia are the non-neuronal cells of the central nervous system
Glial cells are the backbone of the brain

patterns: Which do you think are better neurons or glia
responses: In my opinion glial cells are better than neurons

patterns: Are glial cells only one type of cell
responses: No, there are several different types of glial cells. Some of the cells that are categorized as glial include: astroctes, microglia, and oligodendrocytes

patterns: I dont quite understand what neurons are
responses: A neuron is a specialized cell that transmits nerve impluses

patterns: what are the lobes of the brain
what are the regions of the brain
responses: There are 4 lobes of the brain, the frontal lobe, temporal lobe, occipital lobe and parietal lobe
A nerve impulse is an action potential

patterns: how does an action potential work
responses: Neurons send action potential which are changes in electrical potential associated with the passage of an impulse along the membrane of a nerve cell.

An action potential is an explosion of electrical activity that is created by a depolarizing current. So when the dendrites of one neuron recieves a stimulus from another neuron the receiving neuron membrane becomes more positive resulting in the opening of ion channels. This depolarization travels down the neuron until it reaches the axon and when it reaches the axon if the membrane potential is positive enough an action potential will fire, where the postive potential opens more ion channels continuously make the membrane potential more positive traveling down the axon. Eventually the positive membrane potential will reach the axon terminal and result in the release of neurotransmitters into a synapse
Membrane potential is the difference in electrical potential, or voltage, across the membrane which results from the charge separation between the inside and outside of a cell
The synapse is the junction between two neurons where neurotransmitter is released

patterns: what are the functions of an astrocyte
responses: Astrocytes are star shaped glial cells and have a variety of functions
Astrocytes control cerebral blood flow, maintian the blood brain barrier, metabolize monoamine oxidases, and many more functions
Astrocytes control cerebral blood flow, maintian the blood brain barrier, metabolize monoamine oxidases, and many more functions
Microglia are the immune cells of brain
Microglia phagocytose pathogens in the CNS
oligodendrocyte are the myelinating cells of the central nervous system
oligodendrocyte wrap around the axon of neurons making the myelin sheath
oligodendrocyte wrap around the axon of neurons making the myelin sheath

Myelin is made from oligodendrocytes in the CNS and Schwann cells in the PNS. A myelin sheath wraps around the axon of a neuron and provides structural as well as nutritional support and increases the speed at which impluses are conducted
Neurotransmitters are chemical substances that are released at the end of a nerve fiber by the arrival of an action potential.

Neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and bind to recptors on the dendrites of neurons. The binding of neurotransmitters to recptors results in the opening of channels and an influx of positive ions which can trigger an action potential.
The most known neurotransmitters include glutamate, dopamine, serotonin, GABA, epinephrine, and norepinephrine.

patterns: what are the different types of receptors
are there receptors at a synapse
responses: Receptors are is a molecule in the cell membrane, which reponds specifically to a particular neurotransmitter, hormone, antigen, or other substances.
The receptors present at a synapse are either ionotropic or metabatropic
Yes, receptors are present on the membrane of the post-synaptic neuron
An axon is a long slender projection of the neuron which conducts action potentials
Axon terminals are the signal sending part of the neuron
Dendrites are short brandched extensions of a neuron which receive impulses from other cells are synapses

Ionotropic receptors are membrane-bound receptor proteins that respond to ligand binding by opening an ion channel and allowing ions to flow into the cell, either increasing or decreasing the likelihood that an action potential will fire
Metabotropic receptors are membrane receptors which activate second messengers when a ligand binds
